attributes.comment:
I have two main comments to make, and a suggestion on what to do instead of a
fee increase.

1. I find it hard to believe that the last time fees were increased was 1998. When
my husband and I applied to change his status from fiance visa to permanent
resident, we sent in fees as indicated on forms and had our paperwork sent back
with a notice we didn't pay enough, even though we paid fees as listed on the
forms. We were married and applied in 2001, so unless we were given REALLY
antiquated forms, I could swear they've increased fees more recently.

2. Is their service going to improve as drastically as the fees are increasing?
Including the above listed incident, our paperwork was sent back to us three
times. It was sent back the first time because we sent it to the wrong address.
We followed the directions indicated on the forms. We called for help and after
being on hold for two hours, were given a different address to send the forms. The
forms came back again, BECAUSE THEY WERE SENT TO THE WRONG
ADDRESS! This address was given to us by the representative over the phone!
By this time we were nearing our filing deadline. We checked the forms again and
online and there was only one address left by this time, so we sent it in. Finally it
was to the right place. To add insult to injury, after waiting 28 months, we were
granted our interview. The day of our interview we went where we were supposed
to go in Chicago. We went to one floor to wait and were told to hand our interview
letter in. They would call us to go upstairs when it was our turn. We were there
about an hour early. After waiting about two hours, and noticing people who had
come in after us were getting called before us, I went to the window to try to ask
what happened. I was very rudely told to sit down. I was treated like I was
threatening the woman working at the window instead of trying to ask a question.
After another twenty minutes there was a shift change. I again asked and this
woman told me she would look into it. We were the next people called. We got
upstairs and no sooner sat down then we were called for our interview. The
woman who called us demanded to know why we were late. She said it was the
third time they called us, and were going to consider our
appointment 'abandoned.' I explained how after we turned in our letter downstairs
their people seemed to lose it, and I explained how when I tried to ask about it I
was yellled at. Her response was "Oh." No apology or anything, even though our
being late was their fault. Will these highly inflated fees be used for better
customer service?

Instead of increasing fees and penalizing people who are following the rules, how
about charging fines to the illegal immigrants who enter the country? Don't spend
money to detain and deport them, especially if they have caused any problems.
Just make them pay the fees they should have paid to enter the country legally, at
the 'priority processing' rate, of course, plus a fine of about $5000.00 each. If they
don't have the cash, refer them to a bank to borrow the money. Then, we could
save money by not detaining and deporting them, we could get money from those
entering illegally, they could become legal, and they'd start out in massive debt in
the true American spirit. This would solve many aspects of the problems the US
Citizenship and Immigrations Services are facing.
